title: Independent expenditures skyrocketing
text:
Special interest and major donor independent spending on state candidates has increased 840 percent – from $9.3 million to $78 million – since 2002, according to a report by the campaign finance watchdog group Maplight.
Unfettered by the campaign contribution limits on money given directly to candidate campaigns, independent expenditures allow those with deep pockets to run campaigns parallel to those of the candidates they support.
While the 2010 Citizens United ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court attracted attention to this burgeoning phenomenon on the national level, the growth of in-state independent expenditures was underway well before high court weighed in.
The Maplight report is just the latest tally of the outfall of Proposition 34, approved by 60 percent of voters in 2000. The stated intent of Prop. 34 was to scale back the influence of wealthy interests and donors by establishing limits on what could be given to state legislative and statewide candidates.
But while it limited money going directly to candidates, it started a snowballing of independent expenditures, for which there are no limits.
Democrats have taken advantage of that more than Republicans, with $44 million spent by the Democratic Party in independent expenditures on behalf of state candidates in 2014 and $17.3 million spent by the Republican Party.
Orange County got its share of that action, thanks to a couple races that were supposed to be competitive but turned out to be relatively easy GOP wins.
In the race to replace the seat vacated by termed-out state Sen. Lou Correa , D-Santa Ana, Democrat Jose Solorio received nearly as much help in independent expenditures ($2.8 million) as he raised for his own campaign ($3.1 million). But that wasn’t enough to overcome Republican Janet Nguyen , who got less help in independent expenditures ($2.1 million) but raised more for her own campaign ($3.5 million).
Nguyen prevailed on Election Day, 58 percent to 42 percent.
Incumbent Assemblywoman Sharon Quirk-Silva , D-Fullerton, had a much greater money advantage ($3.7 million spent by her campaign, $1.3 million in independent expenditures) over GOP challenger Young Kim ($2.2 million spent by her campaign, $174,000 in independent expenditures). But it wasn’t enough to turn the tide her way.
Kim prevailed on Election Day, 55 percent to 45 percent.
Maplight hasn’t run recent numbers breaking down the amount of political spending in the state by special interests, but I’d be surprised if the proportions have changed much since their tally for the 2012 election cycle.
Public employees easily led the field with $7 million in spending, followed by: construction unions ($4.4 million), insurance companies ($3.8 million), attorneys and law firms ($3 million), Indian tribes ($2.9 million) and telecommunications interests ($2 million).
Political scofflaws
A couple of fairly minor fines were approved Thursday by the state Fair Political Practices Commission.
Fullerton Councilwoman Jennifer Fitzgerald agreed to pay $100 for not listing her job with the lobbying and public relations firm of Curt Pringle & Associates on her 2015 statement of economic interests. She is a vice president with the firm.
Kermit Marsh has agreed to pay a $200 penalty for his Westminster City Council campaign failing to pay the $50 annual secretary of state fee in 2013.
The sole big Orange County fine approved was $15,000 for longtime trash hauler George Briggeman, Jr. , for masking $13,200 in contributions to a PAC that supported City Council candidates in Cypress, Anaheim and Lake Forest. This has been written about more extensively elsewhere in the Register.
